references: We compare FedDM with four representative iterative model averaging based methods: FedAvg [19], FedProx [34], FedNova [38], and SCAFFOLD [32]. We summarize the action of the client and the server, together with the transmitted message for all methods in Table 1.

references:
In real-world applications, there are various extreme data distributions among clients. To synthesize such non-i.i.d. partitioning, we consider two more scenarios with Dir10​(0.1)subscriptDir100.1\text{Dir}_{10}(0.1) and Dir10​(0.01)subscriptDir100.01\text{Dir}_{10}(0.01). As mentioned, α→0→𝛼0\alpha\rightarrow 0 implies each client holds examples from only one random class. It can be seen in Table 2 that previous methods based on iterative model averaging are insufficient to handle these two challenging scenarios and their performance degrades drastically compared with Dir10​(0.5)subscriptDir100.5\text{Dir}_{10}(0.5).
In contrast, FedDM performs consistently better and more robustly, since distribution matching enables it to approximate the global training objective more accurately.

references: In this section, we provide specific message size under different data partitioning of FedDM. As discussed previously, the message size of all baseline methods are determined on the model size, while the message size varies from different scenarios and ipc values. When there are 101010 clients, we set ipc=10 for MNIST and CIFAR10, and ipc=5 for CIFAR100. We present the results in Table 3. It can be observed that FedDM are more advantageous for unbalanced data partitioning, such as Dir10​(0.1)subscriptDir100.1\text{Dir}_{10}(0.1) and Dir10​(0.01)subscriptDir100.01\text{Dir}_{10}(0.01). For the experiment of Dir50​(0.5)subscriptDir500.5\text{Dir}_{50}(0.5) on CIFAR10 with ConvNet, the message sizes of FedDM and baselines are 3.1×1063.1superscript1063.1\times 10^{6} and 1.6×1071.6superscript1071.6\times 10^{7} respectively, where our method saves about 80%percent8080\% costs per round. Moreover, if the underlying model are changed to ResNet-18 for Dir10​(0.5)subscriptDir100.5\text{Dir}_{10}(0.5), then the number of parameters is about 1.1×1081.1superscript1081.1\times 10^{8}.

A4.T4.table:
ρ𝜌\rho Test accuracy
ρ=3𝜌3\rho=3 69.15 ±plus-or-minus\pm 0.09%
ρ=5𝜌5\rho=5 69.66 ±plus-or-minus\pm 0.13%

references: where we clip the sampled weight to guarantee that ‖w−wr‖2≤ρsubscriptnorm𝑤subscript𝑤𝑟2𝜌\|w-w_{r}\|_{2}\leq\rho. At the server’s side, when training the global model, we also clip the weight to the ρ𝜌\rho-radius ball. We conduct experiments to choose ρ𝜌\rho from [3,5,10]3510[3,5,10] and present the test accuracy after 202020 communication rounds on CIFAR10 under the default Dir10​(0.5)subscriptDir100.5\text{Dir}_{10}(0.5) setting in Table 4. We find that performance is similar and FedDM is not very sensitive to the choice of ρ𝜌\rho. ρ=5𝜌5\rho=5 performs relatively the best and we hypothesize that too small weight makes the optimization of the global model restricted and too big one adds to the difficulty of learning a surrogate function. Based on results in Table 4, we select ρ=5𝜌5\rho=5 for all our experiments.
